importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks the first major test of the US-brokered ceasefire in Gaza, following Israeli strikes after two soldiers were killed, testing the stability of the agreement.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe covers the initial implementation and first major test of the ceasefire agreement, including Israeli strikes, aid delivery, and accusations of violations by both sides.

keyTakeAways: A US-brokered ceasefire between Israel and Hamas has withstood its first major test after Israeli forces killed two soldiers in Gaza, prompting retaliatory airstrikes.

Hamas and the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) both accused each other of violating the ceasefire, with Hamas claiming it was not involved in attacks on Israeli troops and Israel accusing Hamas of launching rocket-propelled grenade attacks in Rafah.
The IDF conducted strikes that killed at least 44 people in Gaza, with scenes of panic reported at hospitals, including al-Aqsa hospital.

Hamas' Al-Qassam Brigades confirmed they remain committed to the ceasefire and found the body of another Israeli hostage during search operations, warning that further escalation would hinder recovery efforts.
Aid deliveries into Gaza were temporarily paused but resumed hours later, indicating continued efforts to uphold the ceasefire’s humanitarian components.
Israel’s National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir criticized the resumption of aid, calling it a 'shameful backdown' despite Hamas’s alleged violations.
The Rafah crossing remains closed as Israel awaits the return of all remaining hostages and the full return of bodies.

Hamas launched a 'security campaign' targeting individuals it labels as collaborators with Israel, including Israel-backed militias, leading to violence and a public execution of eight people in Gaza City.
The US has continued diplomatic engagement, with key architects Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner visiting the region, and US Vice President JD Vance scheduled to visit shortly after.
The ceasefire remains fragile amid conflicting claims over violations, with both parties citing breaches and demanding accountability.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A US-brokered ceasefire between Israel and Hamas appears to have withstood its first major test after Israeli forces killed two soldiers in Gaza, prompting retaliatory airstrikes and accusations of violations from both sides. Despite the escalation, Hamas and the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) both affirmed their commitment to the agreement. The US, through key figures like Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, remains actively involved in diplomatic efforts. Aid deliveries to Gaza were temporarily paused but resumed, signaling efforts to maintain humanitarian components of the ceasefire. Tensions are heightened by claims of attacks in Rafah, where Hamas allegedly targeted an Israel-backed militia, and by accusations that Hamas has not returned all bodies of the deceased hostages. The situation remains volatile, with internal violence in Gaza, including an apparent public execution, and political pressure from Israeli figures like Itamar Ben-Gvir, who criticizes the resumption of aid. The ceasefire remains fragile, and its long-term viability hinges on continued compliance and diplomatic intervention.
title: US-brokered ceasefire appears to survive first major test as Israel and Hamas affirm commitment to deal
